Comment: causes umlaut, shows variation as to loss of obj:w
also contains reflex of *poko 'occ.with'; can occur with TR or INTR
unclear if same morpheme, different interpretations (S/A vs S/P pivot)
Some languages added an element rc:-rə.
Some languages added an element rc:-rə.
The transitive form given in src:panarepayne2013[201] is obj:ni-, but that is inaccurate.

Form: jɨ-; jɨw-; jo-; ju-; ji-; i-

Comment: The form given in src:panarepayne2013[201] is obj:ti-, but that is inaccurate.
Not sure if this triggers stress shift, would make it formally identical to morph:pan_1p
Occurs with morph:pan_1p in 2>1 scenarios. The transitive form given in src:panarepayne2013[201] is obj:mi-, but that is inaccurate.
The form given in src:panarepayne2013[201] is obj:ki-, but that is inaccurate.

Form: ɨt͡ʃ-; as-; əs-; ɨs-; us-; at-; ɨt-; oh-; əʔ-; uʔ-
Comment: The allomorphs are mostly lexically conditioned (src:panarepayne2013[180]).
doubles as nominalizer and NSPEC TAM
With the cons:kar_psthab, there is dialectal variation. src:hoff1968carib[161] documents past habitual forms without obj:i-.
The form given here is a Proto-lg:kalina form, as modern varieties have either deleted initial /ɨ/, or undergone metathesis of /ɨ/ and /j/.

Form: ot-; os-; e-; ai-; oʔ-; as-
Comment: Some verbs show a meaning difference between obj:as- and obj:o-: obj:ene ‘to see’, obj:asene ‘to see oneself’, obj:one ‘to be visible’ (src:courtz2008carib[77]).
can combine with obj:poko; TR or INTR

no umlaut. Given the presence of the linker morph:hix_lk, it is somewhat surprising that this prefix is not obj:roj-/obj:ro-:
ex:hix-34
Even if it had been there at some point, the linker does not leave umlaut traces in lg:hixka (src:meira2010origin[490]).
obj:in- is only attested by other authors; the etymology of obj:je- is unclear
Only occurs on three Sa verbs.

also POSS. The /g/ is unexpected, since lg:ikp /g/ usually comes from rc:k. The related lg:arara form is morph:ara_1p. src:meira2005southern[175] suggest a diachronic development whereby an epenthetic [ɣ] is inserted after obj:ɨ-, with subsequent deletion of obj:ɨ- and fortition to /g/. Such a development is attested in some Tupi-Guarani languages.
obj:kw- before /a/ and /o/; obj:kut͡ʃ- before /i/; obj:kur- before vowels (src:alves2013verbo[180]). No umlaut.
Wrong segmentation as obj:m-iC instead of obj:mi-C.
The form obj:mɨ- only seems to occur with obj:ke/obj:ge ‘to say’.
Etymology of obj:wɨ- unclear so far.
There are more phonologically conditioned allomorphs
obj:kw- before /a/; changes following /e to /i/; deletes high vowels. possible connection to lg:wayana morph:way_1on2?
For a similar development of rc:i-w- in Taranoan, see src:meira1998proto[39--40]

src:cruz2005fonologia gives a conflicting account about whether 2>1 scenarios employ a different marker than 3>1 scenarios; the only potential difference would be that the former does not allow deletion of /u/, but the latter does. Given the distribution of morph:ing_2p (3>2, 1>2, 2P), I have decided to analyze the forms occurring in 2>1 and 3>1 (and 1P) as the same marker.

Form: əj-; ə-; aj-; a-; ej-; e-
eʔ-; es-; eʔ-; ə-; e-; s-

Comment: causes umlaut, also in some Sp verbs
Has a free counterpart obj:tisuɣe. Triggers umlaut (src:kuikurodossantos2007[76]).

Form: at-; ot-; et-; t-; aɣ-; oɣ-; eɣ-; ɣ-; am-; om-; em-; m-
Comment: First person morph:kui_1p deletes the vowel. For second person morph:kui_2p, one can assume vowel harmony with subsequent deletion, while third person morph:kui_3i is zero with no vowel deletion, resulting in identical forms obj:at-/obj:et- etc. /ɣ/ is from rc:r and can be assumed to have arisen from rc:t > rc:r. The origins of /m/ are unclear.
The origins of obj:aw- and obj:V- are unclear.
seems to be innovated from cogset:2pro and cogset:3n; shows ablaut
In intransitive verbs, reflexes of cogset:12a have been merged almost completely with reflexes of cogset:12 (src:pc[Natalia Cáceres]).

Form: ət-; ə-; əʔ-; ot-; oʔ-; o-; at-; a-
Comment: Some verbs show a meaning difference between obj:ə- and obj:ət- (src:maquiritaricaceres2011[132]); there are four Sp verbs which begin with obj:e-, likely a remnant of cogset:refl (src:maquiritaricaceres2011[132])
There are no examples of V-initial transitive or C-initial intransitive verbs, but the form is always given as obj:mon(i)-

This is the third person Sp marker. It seems to have a lexically conditioned allomorph obj:ju- with the verb obj:page ‘to wake up’: ex:ara-43
This allomorph was not found with any other verb.
This is the third person Sa marker.
The deletion of final /i/ is lexically conditioned, and not with the same distribution as the allomorphy of morph:ara_12a (src:alves2017arara[145]).
The deletion of final /i/ is lexically conditioned, and not with the same distribution as the allomorphy of morph:ara_1a (src:alves2017arara[144]).
The form obj:mɨ- only occurs with obj:ke ‘to say’ (src:alves2017arara[150]).
obj:kw- before /a/; obj:kow- before /o/ and /ɨ/; changes following /e to /i/. possible connection to lg:wayana morph:way_1on2?
only INTR, occurs with reflex of *poko or *topo
obj:i- also optionally occurs on C-initial verbs with a preverbal P (src:triomeira1999[289]).
src:meira1998proto[80--81] suggests an extension of the _V allomorph obj:j- to _C position, with insertion of /i/, possibly supported by the reanalysis of verb-initial /i/ as belonging to the prefix.
Lack of umlaut and different C-initial form differentiate it from morph:tri_12a.

Form: ət-; ə-; əəs-; əi-; e-; et-
Comment: Some verbs show free variation, but e.g. obj:epɨ ‘to bathe’ is never rc:əipɨ (src:triomeira1999[255--256]).
Occurs in 1S function only with obj:kɨta ‘shout’ (src:waimiribruno2003[121]).
Can co-occur in 2>1 scenarios with morph:wmr_1p, but not obligatorily (src:waimiribruno2003[123]).
Is combined with morph:wai_1pro in 2>1 scenarios.

Form: et-; es-; et͡ʃ-; eʃ-; ese-; e-

Comment: Only occurs with nonfinite verbs and possessed nouns.
Some verbs take the Sa marker for 1+2, but the Sp markers for other persons.
Some verbs take the Sa marker for 1+2, but the Sp markers for other persons.
The origin of /w/ is unclear, but it is also found in morph:way_2p. Causes mlaut.
with general modifier obj:-tə when with verbs
